thread.title: Gingrich: 'Hillary's problem in debate will be her past'
thread.title_full: Gingrich: 'Hillary's problem in debate will be her past' | Washington Examiner

author: Gabby Morrongiello
title: Gingrich: 'Hillary's problem in debate will be her past'
text:
Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich shared a number of predictions Tuesday morning ahead of the first Democratic debate, including his suggestion that Hillary Clinton's past will come back to haunt her on stage.
The 2012 GOP candidate told Fox News' "Fox and Friends" that the Democratic debate will draw a "very small audience" and be "very boring" in comparison to the first two Republican primary debates, which drew well over 20 million viewers each.
"The 10 million will trail off when Americans realize 'Do you really want to be listening to the five people up there,' " Gingrich said, referring to the anticipated number of viewers for Tuesday's prime-time debate in Las Vegas, Nev.
Clinton, who participated in several presidential primary debates throughout her failed White House bid in 2008, will take center stage as the Democratic front-runner during the first debate.
  Iraqis preparing to retake Ramadi, for real this time Col. Steve Warren said Iraqi ground forces are encircling almost the entire city.
By Jacqueline Klimas • 10/13/15 1:02 PM "Last time she was on stage she was against same-sex marriage, she was a supporter of the Second Amendment, she was behind the Iraq War," host Brian Kilmeade told the former House speaker.
Gingrich added, "Hillary's problem will be they're actually going to remember what she said last time or whether or not she knows Sidney Blumenthal."
Clinton has previously downplayed her relationship with Blumenthal, a long-time friend to her and her husband, former President Bill Clinton. However, new details regarding Blumenthal's level of influence have since emerged with the release of Clinton's private emails from her tenure as secretary of state.
The former first lady will head into Tuesday's debate with roughly 43 percent support among Democratic voters nationwide, according to the latest RealClearPolitics polling average. Several members of the media are predicting a heated battle between Clinton and second-place Democratic hopeful Bernie Sanders during the debate.
